posts.author: BEN DAVIS - Staff Writer
posts.title: Officer recognized for heroism
posts.text:
Save 
MICHIGAN CITY — The Michigan City Police Department heralded the actions of Officer Scott Combs, as well of those by Winter Morgan, who was viciously attacked by a 140-pound bull mastiff on Nov. 10. 
The MCPD awarded Combs for his actions on that day, which according to MCPD chief Mark Swistek, saved Winter's life. 
"On that day, you utilized your prior training, experience, overall physical strength, bravery, along with sound, timely judgement," Swistek said, while presenting Combs with an award for his actions. 
According to Swistek, Combs was first to arrive on the scene of the attack. Out of fear he might harm Winter, who was still being attacked by the 140-pound dog, he elected not to try and shoot the animal, but rather to wrestle the dog, pinning its head to the ground, and allowing Winter to retreat to a safe area. Once the dog was controlled, Combs turned his attention to Winter's wounds. Winter was later airlifted to Riley Children's Hospital in Indianapolis for surgery. 
"He is a hero, as is Winter as well," Swistek said. "Winter is a brave hero for surviving that incident that day. She wasn't trying to fight off the dog, she was as calm as can be. She did the right thing to survive this attack, and is a very, very brave young girl for 12 years old." 
Winter, who is now out of the hospital, but still in recovery from wounds and injuries sustained during the attack, was presented with a bicycle in her favorite color (purple) and also a gift card from the MCPD. 
"She's got a long road to go," said Winter's mother Ruth Hall. "We probably have more trips down to (Indianapolis), she got bit everywhere, (except) her face and her left leg. I'm just glad she is alive, because my first thought was my child is not going to be alive when I got there." 
Hall also added that Winter has had five total surgeries since the attack. 
"Everything is healing well," Hall added. "She might need a another skin graft, she might not." 
Hall also added that Winter has been out of the hospital since Nov. 17. 
Swistek also said the 140-pound male bull mastiff that attacked Morgan was euthanized 10 days later on Nov. 20. Swistek and the MCPD did not release the name of the owner of the dog, as a criminal investigation is still ongoing.

Compiled from Michigan City Police Department reports 
TUESDAY 
James Cobb, 38, of Michigan City was arrested on a La Porte County warrant for battery, an A misdemeanor. 
Fraud was reported in the 600 block of N. Roeske Avenue involving a woman who was allegedly tricked into buying $800 worth of iTune gift cards and giving their numbers to a fake loan agent. 
Shots were reportedly fired in the 3200 block of Salem Court. A spent Winchester .40 S&W casing was found on the sidewalk. 
Clothing was reportedly stolen from Meijer. 
Someone attempted to steal a stereo system, but failed, from a car in the 700 block of E. U.S. 20. 
A girl was arrested for allegedly slapping and knocking the glasses off another student at Michigan City High School.

thread.title: Forget Buying a New Outfit—Try These 7 Holiday Updos That Will Upgrade Your Look
thread.title_full: Forget Buying a New Outfit—Try These 7 Holiday Updos That Will Upgrade Your Look

posts.author: Elizabeth Rich
posts.title: Forget Buying a New Outfit—Try These 7 Holiday Updos That Will Upgrade Your Look
posts.text:
Look fancy without spending a dime. 0 SHARES 
’Tis the season for holiday parties and family get-togethers, which means getting dressed up more than we’re used to. The pressure to buy a last-minute party outfit is real, so instead of dropping more cash this holiday season, try a hairstyle that will do all the work for you. 
A stunning updo can transform any basic ensemble into a regal nighttime look, which is why we’ve rounded up the best tutorials for any holiday event on your calendar. No matter how experienced you are at executing updos, we’ve got a look just for you! For the Low-Maintenance Girl 
If you love a fancy updo but aren’t a fan of the effort, this tutorial from Abby will help you create a sophisticated look without the hard work. Just twist and go! For the Girl Who Likes Hair Accessories 
Perfect for more casual Christmas parties with friends, Ashley’s adorable updos show you how to add accessories without looking too young. For the Girl Who Wants Options 
Ideal for the girl with too many holiday parties and not enough time, Kayley has an updo for every holiday party you could ever anticipate. For the Sleek & Simple Kind of Girl 
If sleek and simple is how you approach any formal event, stick to a polished ponytail that highlights all your features. Dacey shows us exactly how to keep this look secure all night long. For the Bohemian Braid Lover 
While some of us prefer the sleek look, the rest might like something a little more romantic and free-flowing. This bohemian half-up hairdo with a fishtail braid and loose curls by Jackie has us feeling all kinds of festive. For the Girl Who’s Not Scared of a Challenge 
If you face even the most complicated hair tutorial with determination, we think Milabu’s intricate braided updos will be right up your alley. Your family and friends will be impressed with your skills, to say the least. The Girl Who Wants to Master the Basics 
There’s absolutely no shame in not being a hair tutorial pro. Most of us are just looking to master the basics, so if you want to conquer the feminine topknot, look no further than Camila’s classic bun tutorial. Tags

thread.title: 5 – Conference considerations
thread.title_full: 5 – Conference considerations

posts.author: lukearudge
posts.title: 5 – Conference considerations
posts.text:
5 – Conference considerations Standard 
There’s a conference for just about everything nowadays. And no, you don’t have to go to every single one… 
Being able to present your work at a conference is great for a variety of reasons. During doctoral study, I’d recommend going to at least two (e.g. one ‘postgrad’ and one ‘international’) to get feedback on your work, to practice communicating your ideas to a different audience, and to get your face ‘known’ in your research community. The conference might even be in a more exotic part of the world, so why not take a a few days before or after the conference to do some travelling? 
But of course, there’s also a catch or two… 
Conferences can be ridiculously expensive, not only in terms of travel and accommodation, but also just for being able to attend and present the work that you’ve offered to share for free(!). Sometimes there are reduced fees for Ph.D students and part-time staff, but don’t expect it to be cheap in any case. Even conference dinners – that legendary place where (apparently) ‘all the real work gets done’– can cost a ridiculous amount. For example, I recently saw a conference charging nearly £200 as an attendance fee for doctoral students (nearly £300 if you’re full-time staff), and an extra £60 for said conference dinner regardless of your employment status. If you’re an invited speaker, your fees are often paid for you. If you’re not at that stage – and a good number of us aren’t – then best start budgeting (or applying for the scholarships and bursaries that are occasionally offered). 
It’s also worthwhile to consider the number of parallel sessions that will occur. It’s usual to find conferences spanning 3 – 5 days and with a few parallel sessions taking place (i.e. ‘streams’ of presentations occurring at the same time). Even if you’re not presenting, parallel sessions inevitably mean clashes and/or running between rooms to get to the talks you wish to attend. Some conferences have grown so big that there may be 10 (or more!) parallel sessions occurring at any one time… 
Conferences are a key part of the doctoral student experience, but be realistic: balance out how useful attendance will be against costs, time, energy, and likelihood of getting a good audience (especially at the bigger ones). Advertisements

posts.text: Expected better from a ‘luxury’ hotel, but it was just very average. Everything had to be paid, including water, and the room we stayed in was very noisy. I suspect the noise came from someone who was running on threadmill one floor down, and this happened every morning before 7am. Location was very good but other than that, felt slightly better than a no frills hotel in all.
